project.description:
The generated pdf will be emailed to you.

Make sure your Jenkins user email address is valid.

The pdf will also be archived in the build history artifacts.

hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: bam_files
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: comma separated list of .bam files to be processed (with full paths specified)

hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: gff
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: Enter .gff or genomic region e.g. chr1:+:1-1000

hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.name: genome
hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.description: specify a genome, options are hg18 or mm9 right now

hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.name: plot
hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.description: Choose either all lines on a single plot or multiple plots

hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.name: y_scale
hudson.model.ChoiceParameterDefinition.description: Choose either relative or uniform y axis scaling

hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: optional_bam_names
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: Enter a comma separated list of names for your bams (defaults to first section of bam file name, e.g. if the file is /home/data/MM1S_MED1.hg18.bwt.sorted.bam then "MM1S_MED1" will be used as the bam label name on the plot)

hudson.tasks.Shell.command:
rm -rf output # remove any prior output directories mkdir output # create a new output directory
if [ -z "$optional_bam_names" ] then bam_names=`python ~/scripts/defaultBamNames.py "$bam_files"` else bam_names=$optional_bam_names fi
python bamPlot.py -b $bam_files -i $gff -g $genome -n $bam_names -p $plot -y $y_scale -t plot_`date +"%Y-%m-%d_%H%M"`.pdf -o `pwd`/output/
